{{Other people|John MacKenna}} {{Infobox military person |name=Juan Mackenna |image=Juan Mackena.jpg |birth_date={{birth date|1771|10|26|mf=y}} |dead=dead |birth_place=[[Monaghan]], [[Co. Monaghan]], [[Kingdom of Ireland]] |death_date={{death date and age|1814|11|21|1771|10|26|mf=y}} |death_place=[[Buenos Aires]], [[United Provinces of the Río de la Plata]] | allegiance = {{flagicon|Spain|1785}} [[Spain]]
{{flagicon|Chile}} [[Republic of Chile]] | branch = | serviceyears = | rank = | unit = | commands = | battles_label = | battles = [[Siege of Ceuta (1787)|Siege of Ceuta]]
[[War of the Pyrenees]] *[[Siege of Roses (1794–95)|Siege of Roses]] [[Chilean War of Independence]] *[[Battle of Membrillar]] }} [[Brigadier]] '''Juan Mackenna''' (October 26, 1771 – November 21, 1814) was an [[Irish people|Irish-born]], [[Chile]]an military officer and hero of the [[Chilean War of Independence]]. He is considered to have been the creator of the Corps of Military Engineers of the [[Chilean Army]]. ==Early life== He was born '''John MacKenna''' (or '''Seán Mac Cionath''' in [[Irish language|Irish]]) in [[Monaghan]], [[Co. Monaghan]], [[Ireland]], the son of William MacKenna of Willville House near Monaghan town and Eleanora O'Reilly and, on his mother's side, a nephew to [[Count]] [[Alejandro O'Reilly]].Brett, C.E.B. "''Historic Buildings, Groups of Buildings and Areas of Architectural Importance in the Town of Monaghan''". Belfast, Ulster Architectural Heritage Society, 1973, p. 28. Count O'Reilly took an interest in the young Mackenna and took him to [[Enlightenment in Spain|Spain]] where he studied at the Royal School of Mathematics in [[Barcelona]]. He also trained in the Royal Military Academy as a Military Engineer between 1785 and 1791. ===Military career=== In 1787 he was accepted into the Irish Brigade of the [[Spanish army]], and joined the army fighting in [[Ceuta]] in northern Africa, under Lieutenant Colonel [[Luis Urbina]], and was promoted to Second Lieutenant. In 1791 Mackenna resumed his studies in Barcelona and acted as liaison with mercenaries recruited in Europe. The following year he was promoted to Lieutenant in the Royal Regiment of Engineers. In the [[War of the Pyrenees]] against the French, Juan Mackenna fought in [[Rosselló (comarca)|Rosselló]] under General Ricardos and there met the future liberator of Argentina, [[José de San Martín]]. For his exploits in defence of the Plaza de Rozas, he was promoted to captain in 1795. ==Career in Chile== For the purpose of a new assignment, in October 1796, Juan Mackenna left Spain for South America. He arrived in [[Buenos Aires]] and then travelled to [[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]] and to [[Captaincy General of Chile|Chile]] across the Andes and then to [[Viceroyalty of Peru|Peru]]. Once in [[Lima]], he contacted [[Ambrosio O'Higgins]], another Irishman, at that time [[Viceroy]] of Perú, who named him Governor of [[Osorno, Chile|Osorno]] and put him in charge of the reconstruction works for this southern Chilean town.{{sfn|Seccombe|1893}} In this capacity, Juan Mackenna convinced the families of [[Castro, Chile|Castro]], on the island of [[Chiloé Island|Chiloé]], to move to Osorno to found a colony there. He built the storehouse and two mills, as well as the road between Osorno and present-day [[Puerto Montt]]. His successful administration provoked jealousy from Chile's captain-general [[Gabriel de Avilés, 2nd Marquis of Avilés|Gabriel de Avilés]], who feared that Juan Mackenna and Ambrosio O'Higgins would create an Irish colony in Osorno. Both Irishmen were loyal to the Spanish crown, though Juan Mackenna had good relations with O'Higgins' son [[Bernardo O'Higgins|Bernardo]], the future emancipator of Chile, and was also connected with the Venezuelan [[Francisco de Miranda]] and his group of supporters of South American independence. When Ambrosio O'Higgins died in 1801, Avilés was appointed viceroy of Peru. It took him eight years to remove O'Higgins's protégé Juan Mackenna from Osorno. ===Revolutionary wars=== In 1809 Juan Mackenna married Josefina Vicuña y Larraín, an eighteen-year-old Chilean woman from a family with revolutionary connections, with whom he had three children: María del Carmen Dolores, Juan Francisco María del Tránsito, and Félix. After the Declaration of Chilean Independence in 1810, he adhered to the [[Patriotism|Patriot]] side and was commissioned by the first Chilean government to prepare a plan for the defense of the country and oversaw the equipment of the new [[Chilean Army]]. At this juncture he trained the first military engineers for the new army. The following year he was called to the defence committee of the new Republic of Chile, and in 1811 was appointed governor of [[Valparaíso, Chile|Valparaíso]]. Owing to political feuds with [[José Miguel Carrera]] and his brothers, Juan Mackenna was dismissed from the post and taken prisoner. He was a firm ally of [[Bernardo O'Higgins]], who appointed him as one of the key officers to fight the Spanish army of General [[Antonio Pareja]]. Mackenna's major military honour was attained in 1814 at the [[Battle of Membrillar]], in which the general assured a temporary collapse of the royal forces. As a reward for his victory, he was appointed commandant-general by Bernardo O'Higgins, but after a coup d'état led by [[Luis Carrera]] he was exiled to [[United Provinces of the Río de la Plata|Argentina]] in 1814, when Carrera took over power. Juan Mackenna died in [[Buenos Aires]] late in 1814, after a duel with Luis Carrera.{{sfn|Seccombe|1893}} ==Public commemoration in Monaghan== A bust of General MacKenna was publicly presented to Monaghan County Museum on 5 August 2004 by his direct descendant [[:es:Luis Valentín Ferrada]].{{cite web |url=http://www.irishidentity.com/geese/stories/djuanmckenna.htm |title=Co-Liberator of Chile |website=Irish Identity |accessdate=2016-07-13}} At the presentation ceremony General MacKenna, the man "unreservedly regarded as the greatest of Co. Monaghan's exiles" was commemorated in speeches by Most Rev. Dr Joseph Duffy, Bishop of Clogher and by his descendant Senor Ferrada who declared, "In this city of Monaghan, very near to Willville House, the tombs of my ancestors are in the old cemetery. There, my own blood is interred in the sacred earth." ==Family== Mackenna was the great-grandfather of Chilean composer [[Carmela Mackenna]].{{cite web |url=http://www.memoriachilena.cl/602/w3-article-92942.html|title=Carmela Mackenna Subercaseaux (1879-1962)}}{{cite web |url=http://www.genealog.cl/Chile/M/Mackenna/|title=GENEALOGIA DE LA FAMILIA MACKENNA}} ==See also== *[[Treaty of Lircay]] *[[Chilean War of Independence]] *[[History of Chile]] *[[Benjamín Vicuña Mackenna]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{Cite Appletons'|wstitle=Mackenna, Juan|year=1900|notaref=x |short=x}} * {{cite DNB|wstitle=Mackenna, John |first=Thomas |last=Seccombe|volume=35}} ==Sources== *{{cite book |last=Barros Arana |first=Diego |authorlink=Diego Barros Arana |editor= |others= |title=Historia Jeneral de la Independencia de Chile |url= |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume=I-IV |origyear= |year=1855 |publisher=Imprenta del Ferrocarril |location=Santiago, Chile |language=Spanish |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}} *{{cite book |last=Gay |first=Claudio |authorlink=Claudio Gay |editor= |others= |title=Historia de la Independencia Chilena |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9pEOAAAAQAAJ&printsec=titlepage |format= |accessdate= |edition= |series= |volume=I & II |origyear= |year=1856 |publisher=Imprenta de E. Thunot y Cia. |location=Paris, France |language=Spanish |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages= |chapter= |chapterurl= |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}} revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''Kakpokpo Okon''' was an Ibibio prince from the [[Obong Okon Ita]] Kingdom around 1690-1720. He was the son of the marriage between the king and an Igbo woman from the [[Eze Agwu]] lineage. Kakpokpo Okon lead a successful coup against his brother [[Akpan Okon]] the ''Obong'' (king) with the support of the [[Eze Agwu]], [[Nnachi]], and the [[Nnubi dynasty]] in the final phases of the [[Aro-Ibibio Wars]]. Despite the fact that the coup was successful, Kakpokpo Okon was killed in combat.
==External links == *http://www.aro-okigbo.com/history_of_the_aros.htm *https://web.archive.org/web/20081121232256/http://www.aronetwork.org/others/arohistory.html *http://www.aronewsonline.com/origincivilization.html
{{DEFAULTSORT:Okon, Kakpokpo}} [[Category:Aro people]] [[Category:18th-century Nigerian people]] [[Category:Nigerian royalty]] [[Category:Ibibio people]]
{{Nigeria-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = [[Excellency|Her Excellency]] |name = Leona Marlin-Romeo |image = Leona Marlin-Romeo.jpg |office = 5th [[Prime Minister of Sint Maarten]] |monarch = [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands|Willem-Alexander]] |governor = [[Eugene Holiday]] |deputy = |term_start = 15 January 2018 |term_end = |succeeding = |predecessor = [[Rafael Boasman]] |successor = |office1 = |term_start1 = |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = |successor1 = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|7|3|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Sint Maarten]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[United Democrats (Sint Maarten)|United Democrats]] {{small|(2018–present)}}{{cite news|title=UP and DP merge as ‘United Democrats’|url=https://www.thedailyherald.sx/islands/72441-up-and-dp-merge-as-united-democrats|work=The Daily Herald|date=5 January 2018}}{{cite news|title=MPs, former ministers on United Democrats slate|url=https://www.thedailyherald.sx/islands/72480-mps-former-ministers-on-united-democrats-slate|work=The Daily Herald|date=5 January 2018}} |otherparty = {{plainlist| * [[United People's Party (Sint Maarten)|United People's Party]] {{small|(2016–2017)}} * [[Independent politician|Independent]] {{small|(2014-16)}} * [[United St. Maarten Party]] {{small|(2014)}} * [[National Alliance (Sint Maarten)|National Alliance]] {{small|(until 2014)}}}} |spouse = Richard Marlin |children = 2 |alma_mater = [[University of Amsterdam]]
[[Adelphi University]] |religion = |signature = |website = }} '''Leona M. Marlin-Romeo''' (born 3 July 1973) is a [[Sint Maarten]] politician and the current [[Prime Minister of Sint Maarten]]. She was selected as Prime Minister in the coalition agreement between the [[United People's Party (Sint Maarten)|United People's Party]], the [[Democratic Party Sint Maarten|Democratic Party]] and the independent member of Parliament Chanel Brownbill.{{cite news|title=Leona new prime minister, ministers take oath Mon.|url=https://www.thedailyherald.sx/islands/72687-leona-new-prime-minister-ministers-take-oath-mon|work=The Daily Herald|date=12 January 2018}} She previously served as a Member of [[Estates of Sint Maarten|Parliament]] from 2014 to 2016.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ecsxm.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Declaration-Art.-53-LRM.jpg |title=Verklaring ingevolge artikel 53 Landsverordering Registratie en Financien Politieke Partijen |language=Dutch |publisher=Electoral Council of Sint Maarten |date= |accessdate=3 January 2018}} She was sworn in with her [[First Marlin-Romeo cabinet|cabinet]] on 15 January 2018.{{cite news|title=New Interim Council of Ministers sworn-in headed by Prime Minister Leona Marlin-Romeo|url=http://www.soualiganewsday.com/local/soualiga-news-today/item/17571-new-interim-council-of-ministers-sworn-in-headed-by-prime-minister-leona-marlin-romeo.html|work=Soualiga Newsday|date=15 January 2018}} __TOC__ ==Early life== Leona Marlin-Romeo was born on 3 July 1973 on [[Sint Maarten]] to Marius Romeo and Marilyn Thomas. As a child Marlin-Romeo attended the Methodist Agogic Center (MAC) in Sint Maarten. She briefly attended St. Maarten Academy before transferring to [[Oak Hill Academy (Mouth of Wilson, Virginia)|Oak Hill Academy]] in Virginia. She graduated from [[Adelphi University]] in 1995 with a Bachelor’s degree in Political Science and a minor in French. She continued her education at the [[University of Amsterdam]] where she graduated with a Master’s degree in International Relations. In 2005, Marlin-Romeo returned to Sint Maarten, and began working as the Head of the Civil Registry Department.{{cite web|url=http://data.sxmelections.com/united-peoples-party/marlin-romeo-leona/645/bio.aspx|title=Bio - Leona Marlin-Romeo|website=SXM Elections|accessdate=3 January 2018}}{{cite news|title=Leona Marlin, Dr. Lloyd Richardson go 'forward together' with 'winning team'|url=http://www.thedailyherald.info/subscribers/clients-files/2010/08-Aug-2010/Aug-16-10.pdf|work=The DailyHerald|date=16 August 2010|pages=1, 5,}} ==Personal life== Marlin-Romeo has been married to Richard Marlin since 1997, the couple has two children.{{cite news|title=Toastmasters Clubs to host Area Debate|url=http://www.thedailyherald.info/subscribers/clients-files/2013/05May2013/May-23-2013.pdf|work=The Daily Herald|date=23 May 2013|page=10}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[List of Sint Maarten leaders of government]] {{Prime Ministers of Sint Maarten}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marlin-Romeo, Leona}} [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women prime ministers]] [[Category:Sint Maarten politicians]] [[Category:Female heads of government]] [[Category:Sint Maarten women in politics]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of Sint Maarten]] [[Category:United St. Maarten Party politicians]] [[Category:National Alliance (Sint Maarten) politicians]] [[Category:United People's Party (Sint Maarten) politicians]] [[Category:University of Amsterdam alumni]] [[Category:Adelphi University alumni]] [[Category:Toastmasters members]] {{SintMaarten-stub}} {{Netherlands-politician-stub}}

{{Infobox CFL player | fontcolor = | name = Lindy Berry | image = | Imagewidth = | caption = | status = Retired | import = yes | birth_date = {{birth date|1927|12|21}} {{cite web|url=http://www.fanbase.com/Lindy-Berry |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013003424/http://www.fanbase.com/Lindy-Berry |archivedate=2012-10-13 |df= }} | birth_place = [[Wichita Falls, Texas]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|4|19|1927|12|21}} | death_place = [[Fort Worth, Texas]] | height_ft = | height_in = | weight_lbs = | position1 = Quarterback | position2 = Kick returner | position3 = Punt returner | College = [[TCU Horned Frogs football|Texas Christian]] | high_school = [[Wichita Falls High School|Wichita Falls]] | NFLDraftedYear = 1950 | NFLDraftedRound = 7 | NFLDraftedPick = 89 | NFLDraftedTeam = [[San Francisco 49ers]] | CommonDraftedYear = | CommonDraftedRound = | jersey = 43 | TSNAllAFL = | CFLAllStar = {{CFL Year|1950}} | ProBowls = | Awards = {{CFL Year|1950}} [[Jeff Nicklin Memorial Trophy]] | Honors = 1948 All-[[Southwest Conference]]
1949 All-America first team
1949 All-Southwest Conference
{{CFL Year|1950}} All-West second team (CFL) | PFR = | NFL = | CBS = | DatabaseFootball = | ESPN = | SportsIllustrated = | playing_years1 = {{CFL Year|1950}}–{{CFL Year|1951}} | playing_team1 = [[Edmonton Eskimos]] }} '''Lindy Berry''' (December 21, 1927 – April 19, 2014) Hanna, Bill (April 23) "Lindy Berry, a former TCU All-America quarterback, dies at 86," ''Star-Telegram'' (Ft. Worth) 23 April 2014 (no time stamp). http://www.star-telegram.com/2014/04/22/5757930/lindy-berry-a-former-tcu-all-america.html?rh=1 was an American gridiron football [[quarterback]]. He played [[college football]] for the [[TCU Horned Frogs football|TCU Horned Frogs]] at [[Texas Christian University]]. Berry was selected in the [[1950 NFL Draft]], and played professional football for two seasons with the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] in what later became the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL). In 1950, he received the [[Jeff Nicklin Memorial Trophy]] for the CFL West Division's [[most valuable player]]. ==Early life== Berry attended [[Wichita Falls High School]] in [[Wichita Falls, Texas]]. While there, he played [[high school football|football]] under head coach [[Thurman Jones|Thurman "Tugboat" Jones]]. During his junior season in 1944, he led the Coyotes to an 8–3 record and the district championship. Nevertheless, Berry said, "There was this café in town where people went on Saturday mornings to rehash the game from the night before. One morning I heard a couple of guys in there talking about me. One said, 'He will never make it.' I said to myself, 'We'll see.'"[http://m.timesrecordnews.com/news/2008/Jun/21/gholson-nick-time-june-21/ Gholson: In the Nick of Time] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717060352/http://m.timesrecordnews.com/news/2008/Jun/21/gholson-nick-time-june-21/ |date=2011-07-17 }}, ''[[Times Record News]]'', June 21, 2008. As a senior in 1945, Berry led Wichita Falls to an 11–1–1 record. The Coyotes' sole loss was to the eventual state champions, [[Highland Park High School (University Park, Texas)|Highland Park High School]], which eliminated Wichita Falls in the semifinals. ==College career== Berry attended [[Texas Christian University]] where he played on the [[TCU Horned Frogs football|Horned Frogs]] varsity football team all four seasons. In addition to playing quarterback, he was also TCU's [[punt returner|punt]] and [[kickoff returner]] and played [[Safety (American football position)|safety]] on defense. His [[forward pass|passing]] duo with [[end (American football)|end]] [[Morris Bailey]] was nicknamed the "Berry-to-Bailey Battery."[http://www.amarillo.com/stories/071902/obi_executivedies.shtml Retired business executive dies at age 77], ''[[Amarillo Globe-News]]'', July 20, 2002. Wichita Falls' ''[[Times Record News]]'' reported an incident that demonstrated Berry was "tough as nails". In one unspecified game against the [[Texas Longhorns football|Texas Longhorns]], Berry dropped back in the [[passing pocket|pocket]] looking to pass. A Longhorns defender, [[Errol Fry]], dodged a [[blocking (American football)|block]] and [[quarterback sack|sacked]] Berry. During the [[tackle (football move)|tackle]], Fry's elbow struck Berry in the face and knocked out two of his front teeth and [[mandibular fracture|broke his jaw]]. Nevertheless, Berry played the following week, while wearing a [[goaltender mask|hockey mask]] to protect his jaw that had been wired shut. He earned his first [[Letterman (sports)|letter]] as a freshman in 1946.[http://gofrogs.cstv.com/photos/schools/tcu/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/0809-mg-sec1-137-158.pdf Records], ''2008 TCU Football Media Guide'', p. 172, 2008. In 1947, he led the team in passing with 429 yards, 31 [[completion (American football)|completion]]s on 67 attempts, and one [[touchdown]]. He also led the team in [[rush (American football)|rush]]ing with 379 yards on 112 attempts and four [[touchdown]]s. In 1948, Berry recorded 706 passing yards, 61 completions on 134 attempts, and two touchdowns. Midway through the season, he ranked second in the nation in total offensive yards until surpassed by [[Charlie Justice (American football player)|Charlie Justice]] of [[North Carolina Tar Heels football|North Carolina]].[http://www.scott.k12.va.us/gchsfootball/1948%20Articles/48coeburn.pdf Present Army Duo Eyes New Cadet Record]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (PDF), [[Associated Press]], 1948. Berry finished the season as the team's rushing leader with 783 yards on 190 attempts and four touchdowns.Records, p. 142. He was named an All-[[Southwest Conference]] selection.Records, p. 169. He also received the Rogers Trophy as the team's [[most valuable player]].Records, p. 170. In 1949, Berry compiled 1,445 passing yards, 106 completions on 220 attempts, and seven touchdowns.Records, p. 145. He also threw 23 [[interception]]s, which to date remains the school record. He was named a first-team All-American and an All-Southwest Conference selection.Records, p. 168. After the season, he participated in the [[East-West Shrine Game]].Records, p. 171. During that season, he compiled 1,445 passing yards in 10 games. At the time, only one other TCU quarterback had exceeded that in a season, [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Davey O'Brien]], and he had the benefit of playing in one additional game. During his college career, Berry had recorded 1,745 rushing yards, 1,372 punt return yards, 729 kickoff return yards, 185 interception return yards, and 32 receiving yards. He graduated from TCU as its all-time career leader in all-purpose yardage, a distinction which stood through the mid-1980s when his mark was surpassed by [[Tony Jeffery]].Records, p. 148. Berry's 2,101 total kick return yards set a school record that stood until 2005, when it was broken by [[Cory Rodgers]].[http://www.packers.com/draft/2006/coryrodgers.phtml Cory Rodgers] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211051028/http://www.packers.com/draft/2006/coryrodgers.phtml |date=2009-02-11 }}, [[Green Bay Packers]], retrieved July 19, 2009. ==Professional career== Berry was selected in the seventh round of the [[1950 NFL Draft]] by the [[San Francisco 49ers]] as the 89th overall pick.[https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/sfo/1950_draft.htm 1950 San Francisco 49ers Draftees], Pro Football Reference, retrieved July 19, 2009. He played two seasons for the [[Edmonton Eskimos]] in what later became known as the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL) from 1950 to 1951.[http://www.esks.com/page/history-honourroll Roll of Honour] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204000110/http://esks.com/page/history-honourroll |date=2014-12-04 }}, [[Edmonton Eskimos]], retrieved July 19, 2009.Matt Vautour, [http://www.magarchive.tcu.edu/articles/2002-03-RR.asp Brave heart], ''TCU Magazine'', March 2002. He was awarded the [[Jeff Nicklin Memorial Trophy]] in 1950 as the West Division's [[most valuable player]].[http://cflapedia.com/awards/outstanding_player.htm Outstanding Player Award], CFLapedia, retrieved July 19, 2009. He was named to the CFL's 1950 All-West second team.Bob Braunwart and Bob Carroll, [http://www.profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/08-An-02.pdf Canadian All-Stars, 1932-50] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127055806/http://profootballresearchers.org/Coffin_Corner/08-An-02.pdf |date=2010-11-27 }} (PDF), ''Coffin Corner'', Vol. 8, PFRA Annual 1986, p. 5, Pro Football Researchers Association, 1986. ==Personal life== In 1951, Berry married Mary, the secretary of his former college coach [[Dutch Meyer]]. Their grandson, Charlie Berry, played for Highland Park High School and the [[SMU Mustangs football|SMU Mustangs]] at [[Southern Methodist University]] as a [[defensive lineman]].[http://smumustangs.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/berry_charlie00.html Charlie Berry] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115200427/http://smumustangs.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/berry_charlie00.html |date=2007-11-15 }}, Southern Methodist University, retrieved July 19, 2009. Since those are both rivals of the elder Berry's [[alma mater]]s, he said, "It wasn't easy but I had to cheer for Charlie." Berry was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] in 2004. In 2008, he was inducted into the [[Oil Bowl (high school)|Oil Bowl]] Hall of Fame, which honors the most outstanding past participants of a high school football all-star game between Texas and Oklahoma players.[http://www.oilbowl.com/fame.php Hall of Fame] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617101252/http://www.oilbowl.com/fame.php |date=2010-06-17 }}, [[Oil Bowl (high school)|Oil Bowl]], retrieved July 19, 2009. That same year, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' listed him among six others as "worthy of consideration" as the best player to have ever worn the [[squad number|number]] 43.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2008/football/ncaa/01/03/worthy/ Worthy of Consideration Honorable Mention: Best College Players by Number], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', January 3, 2008. Berry is the great-uncle of Lana Berry, a popular figure on Twitter and other social media sites, and sports podcaster. [https://soundcloud.com/thelanaberryshow/episode-26-marshall-newhouse] ==See also== * [[List of NCAA major college yearly punt and kickoff return leaders]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{TCU Horned Frogs quarterback navbox|state=collapsed}} {{Jeff Nicklin pre 1973}} {{EskimosQuarterback}} {{CFL passing yardage leaders}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berry, Lindy}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:American football quarterbacks]] [[Category:American players of Canadian football]] [[Category:Canadian football quarterbacks]] [[Category:Edmonton Eskimos players]] [[Category:People from Wichita Falls, Texas]] [[Category:People with Parkinson's disease]] [[Category:Players of American football from Texas]] [[Category:TCU Horned Frogs football players]]

page.title: List of people in the Hebrew Bible called Shemaiah

revision.comment: added article name for Easton's citation
revision.text:
'''Shemaiah''' is the name of several people in the [[Hebrew Bible]] (Hebrew: שמעיה ''shemayah'' "God Heard"): *a Levite in the time of [[David]], who with 200 of his relatives took part in the bringing up of the ark from Obed-edom to [[Hebron]] (I Chronicles 15:8) *the eldest son of Obed-edom (I Chronicles 26:4-8) *Shemaiah son of Nethanel, a scribe mentioned as active at the death of [[David]] (I Chronicles 24:6) *[[Shemaiah (prophet)|Shemaiah]], a [[prophet]] in the reign of [[Rehoboam]] ([[Books of Kings|I Kings]] 12:22-24) *one of the Levites whom [[Jehoshaphat]] appointed to teach the law (II Chronicles 17:8) *Shemaiah, the father of Shimri, listed as a [[Tribe of Simeon|Simeonite]] five generations before the reign of [[Hezekiah]] ([[Books of Chronicles|I Chronicles]] 4:37) *Shemaiah son of Jeduthun, a Levite in the time of Hezekiah (II Chronicles 29:14) *a Levite appointed to "distribute the oblations of the Lord" during the reign of [[Hezekiah]] (II Chronicles 31:15) *a Levite in the time of [[Josiah]] (II Chronicles 35:9) *the father of [[Urijah]] the prophet (Jeremiah 26:20) *the father of a prince in the reign of [[Jehoiakim]] (Jeremiah 36:12) *Shemaiah the Nehelamite, a false prophet who went with the captives to Babylon and who opposed [[Jeremiah]] (Jeremiah 29:24, 31-32). *Shemaiah son of Galal, a Levite listed as the father of a man living in the city of Jerusalem after the end of the [[Babylonian captivity]] [[Levite]] (I Chronicles 9:16) *Shemaiah son of Shechaniah, listed among those who made repairs to the wall of Jerusalem in [[Book of Nehemiah|Nehemiah]] 3:29 *Shemaiah son of Delaiah, a [[false prophet]] who hindered the rebuilding of [[Jerusalem]] (Nehemiah 6:10) *a [[priest]] involved in the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 12:42) *Shemaiah the son of Hasshub, a Levite listed as living in the city of [[Jerusalem]] after the end of the Babylonian captivity (I Chronicles 9:14; Nehemiah 11:15) *a prince of [[tribe of Judah|Judah]] who assisted at the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem (Nehemiah 12:34-36)
The second book of [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] refers to a "Book of the Prophet Shemaiah". No existing work has been identified with this title (see [[Lost books of the Old Testament]]).
==See also== *[[Shema (disambiguation)]] *[[Shemaiah (disambiguation)]] *[[List of minor biblical figures, L–Z#S]]
{{Eastons|Shemaiah}}
[[Category:Hebrew Bible people|Shemaiah]] [[Category:Bible-related lists of people|Shemaiah]]

{{infobox military person |image = Long Jiguang.jpg |birth_date = 1867 |birth_place = [[Yunnan]] Province, {{flagicon|Qing Dynasty}}[[Qing Empire]] |death_date = March 12, 1925 |death_place = [[Beijing]], {{flagicon|ROC|1925}}[[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republic of China]] |allegiance = {{plainlist| *[[Qing Dynasty]] [[Beiyang clique]] }} |battles = {{plainlist| *[[Xinhai Revolution]] *[[Second Revolution (China)|Second Revolution]] *[[National Protection War]] *[[Constitutional Protection War]] *[[Zhili-Anhui War]] }} }} {{chinese |pic=File:Long Jinguang and Long Jiguang.jpg |picsize=200px |Long Jiguang (''right'') with his brother in Guangzhou |s={{linktext|龙|济|光}} }} '''Long Jiguang''' (龍濟光) (1867–1925) was an ethnic [[Hani people|Hani]] Chinese general of the late Qing and early Republican period of [[China]].
==Biography== Long's older brother Jinguang (龍覲光) was also a general. Long began his military career suppressing anti-Qing rebellion by Republican revolutionaries in China. After the fall of the Qing, he supported [[Yuan Shi-kai]] against [[Sun Yat-sen]]. After Yuan created the [[Empire of China]], Long fought against the [[Guangxi]] warlords Lu Rongting and [[Li Liejun]], who opposed Yuan's restoration of the monarchy. An opponent of the [[Constitutional Protection Movement]], Yuan fled southern China to Beijing, where he supported [[Duan Qirui]] and the [[Anhui clique]] until their defeat in the [[Zhili-Anhui War]]. Long died in Beijing on the same day as Sun Yat-sen.
[[Ye Ju]] was one of his lieutenants.
==External links== {{Commonscat|Long Jiguang}}
[[Category:Hani people]] [[Category:1867 births]] [[Category:1925 deaths]] [[Category:Qing dynasty generals]] [[Category:Republic of China warlords from Yunnan]] [[Category:People from Honghe]] [[Category:Republic of China people born during Qing]] [[Category:Empire of China (1915–1916)]]

revision.text:
'''Michael Steinberger''' is an American author and journalist, and was the [[wine]] [[columnist]] of the internet magazine ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' from 2002 to 2011.<ref name=drv258>Colman, Tyler, drvino.com (August 25, 2011). [http://www.drvino.com/2011/08/25/mike-steinberger-slate-wine/ The budgetary ax cuts Slate’s wine column]</ref> He has been described as "one of the greatest wine writers on the planet",<ref name=drvino>{{cite web| last= Colman |first= Tyler, drvino.com |title= Great wine, great writing: the 1947 Cheval Blanc and Mike Steinberger |url= http://www.drvino.com/2008/02/14/great-wine-great-writing-the-1947-cheval-blanc-and-mike-steinberger/ |date= February 14, 2008 }}</ref> and to possess a "blessedly trustworthy voice and [[palate]]".<ref name=af>{{cite web |last= Feiring |first= Alison, alicefeiring.com |title= Michael Steinberger on the Future (of wine writing) |url= http://www.alicefeiring.com/winebitch/000414.html |date= April 8, 2008 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080412063725/http://www.alicefeiring.com/winebitch/000414.html |archivedate= April 12, 2008 |df= }}</ref> Steinberger has himself stated his palate is Euro-centric, having been cultivated on [[French wine]], with the wine from [[Bordeaux wine|Bordeaux]] and [[Burgundy wine|Burgundy]] being his "touchstones".<ref>Steinberger, Mike, ''The Washington Post'' (June 19, 2008). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2008/06/18/DI2008061802177.html Discussions: Fine Wines, and Wines That Are Fine]</ref> He currently resides in Hockessin, Delaware with his wife and two kids.
==Career== Steinberger has previously worked as a [[Hong Kong]] correspondent for ''[[Maclean's]]''.<ref name=bl>Booklounge.ca [http://www.booklounge.ca/author/results.pperl?authorid=77713 Author spotlight: Michael Steinberger]</ref> He has also contributed to publications such as ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name=nytms>{{cite web| last=Steinberger |first= Michael, ''The New York Times'' |title= Drinking Deeply |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/22/books/review/Steinberger.t.html |date= October 22, 2006 }}</ref><ref name=nytms2>{{cite web| last=Steinberger |first= Michael, ''The New York Times'' |title= What Would Bacchus Do? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/04/books/review/Steinberger-t.html |date= November 4, 2007}}</ref> ''[[Saveur]]'', ''[[Financial Times]]'',<ref name=msft>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''Financial Times'' |title= New voice on the grapevine |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/92d94ba6-24e4-11d8-81c6-08209b00dd01,id=030808004410.html |date=August 8, 2003 }}</ref> ''[[The Economist]]'', ''[[Food & Wine Magazine|Food & Wine]]'',<ref name=f&wms>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Michael, ''Food & Wine'' |title= Become a Wine Expert in 28 Days |url= http://www.foodandwine.com/articles/become-a-wine-expert-in-28-days |date= February 2007 }}</ref> ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'', ''[[Wine Spectator]]'',<ref name=ws>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Michael, ''Wine Spectator'' |title= Triumph at Taillevent |url= https://wwws.winespectator.com/Wine/Archives/Show_Article/0,1275,3875,00.html |date= October 15, 2002 }}</ref> ''[[The World of Fine Wine]]'',<ref name=wofw-ms>{{cite web |last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''The World of Fine Wine'' |title= Everyone a Critic. The Future of Wine Writing |url= http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |date= March 2008 |format= PDF |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110519182406/http://www.finewinemag.com/docs/SteinbergerWineWriting.pdf |archivedate= 2011-05-19 |df= }}</ref> and ''[[Sommelier Journal]]''.<ref name=sommj-ms>{{cite web |last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''Sommelier Journal'' |title= The Ultimate Service of a Sommelier May Be Through Education |url= http://www.sommelierjournal.com/articles/article.aspx?year=2009&month=02&articlenum=74 |date= February 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110716104225/http://www.sommelierjournal.com/articles/article.aspx?year=2009&month=02&articlenum=74 |archivedate= 2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> Steinberger's ''Slate'' column that had run since June, 2002 was terminated as a result of layoffs by ''Slate'' parent company [[The Washington Post Company]] in August, 2011.<ref name=drv258/><ref>Hagey, Keach, ''Politico.com'' (August 24, 2011). [http://www.politico.com/blogs/onmedia/0811/Slate_lays_off_four_including_Jack_Shafer.html Slate lays off four, including Jack Shafer]</ref>
Steinberger's book ''Au Revoir to All That'' was published in June, 2009.
=={{anchor|Responses}}Controversy== One of Steinberger's articles published by ''Slate'' in 2002, "Grape Rot: The New Wine Spectator's Distinct Aroma of Fishiness",<ref name=sl-wsrot>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first=Mike, ''Slate'' | title= Grape Rot: The New Wine Spectator's Distinct Aroma of Fishiness; Wine Spectator defends its Honor |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2075720/ |date= December 26, 2002 }}</ref> led to a harsh response by ''Wine Spectator'' executive editor Tom Matthews. Steinberger's articles were no longer published in ''Wine Spectator'' after the article, and Matthews demanded a retraction of the article, while recommending that ''Slate'' "no longer accept Steinberger's unprofessional and potentially libelous contributions".
An article that revealed Steinberger's distaste for the [[Sauvignon blanc]] grape, "White Lies: Why Sauvignon Blanc is Overrated",<ref name=ms-sb>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''Slate'' |title = White Lies: Why Sauvignon Blanc is Overrated |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2139871/ |date=April 18, 2006 }}</ref> was widely met with surprise by the wine writers' community.<ref name=nytea>{{cite web| last= Asimov |first= Eric, ''The New York Times'': The Pour |title= Easygoing Califonians |url= http://thepour.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/22/easygoing-californians/ |date= July 22, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=vinog>{{cite web| last= Yarrow |first= Alder, Vinography.com |title= Why Slander a Grape? |url= http://www.vinography.com/archives/2006/04/why_slander_a_grape.html |date= April 22, 2006 }}</ref>
In a ''Slate'' article titled "Change We Can Taste", written concerning an interview with [[White House]] food and beverage operations usher Daniel Shanks published on ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg.com]]'',<ref>McCoy, Elin, ''Bloomberg.com'' (September 18, 2008). [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aYT1uP1dkSPI White House Wine Jeeves Picks Bottles for 'Presence']</ref> Steinberger called for a new "wine policy" for the [[Barack Obama|Obama presidency]].<ref name=ms-ch>{{cite web|last= Steinberger |first= Mike, ''Slate'' |date= January 14, 2009 |title= Change We Can Taste |url= http://www.slate.com/id/2208229/pagenum/all }}</ref> Coining the term "Shafer-gate", in reference to the serving of bottles of "extravagant" 2003 Shafer Hillside Select, costing around $250 a bottle, at a November 2008 emergency economic summit, the article described the [[George W. Bush|Bush era]] tactics of "[[shock and awe]]" in terms of wine policy, achieved with what Steinberger calls "fruit bombs"; he wrote that the White House wine service had been "hostage to a profoundly misguided strategy", and pointed to Obama's opportunity "to act swiftly and boldly on the wine front".<ref name=ms-ch/> When the article was described by ''[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter.com]]'' to have "slammed the White House wine policy",<ref>{{cite web|last= Shaw |first= Lucy, ''Decanter.com'' |title= Obama urged to change White House wine policy |date= January 28, 2009 |url=http://www.decanter.com/news/275955.html }}</ref> its contents were quoted and reiterated without any element of [[satire]].
== See also == *[[List of wine personalities]]
==References== <!-- {{refbegin}} {{refend}} ;Footnotes --> {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://winediarist.com/ Mike Steinberger's Wine Diarist]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Moore | image = Town crier Peter Moore.JPG | image_size = 200x300px | alt = | caption = Peter Moore | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1939|08|29}} | birth_place = [[Walsall]], [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2009|12|20|1939|08|29}} | death_place = [[Wandsworth]], [[London]], England | nationality = [[British people|British]] | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = [[town crier]] }}
'''Peter Moore''' (29 August 1939 – 20 December 2009) was a British town crier. He worked for the London Tourist Board, the Mayor of London, the cities of London and Westminster, and the boroughs of Southwark, Kingston upon Thames, Tower Hamlets, Merton, Haringey, Redbridge and Ealing.
==Life== Moore was born in Walsall, West Midlands, England, to a "father unknown". He was raised in a nearby [[Barnardo's|Barnardo's Home]]. He left Walsall for London, and became an actor.<ref name="TimesEngland">{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article6974553.ece | title=Peter Moore: London’s town crier | work=The Times | date=4 January 2010 | accessdate=16 May 2011}}</ref> He was cast in the original 1960 stage production of [[Lionel Bart| Lionel Bart’s]] ''[[Oliver!]]'', as the undertaker Mr. Sowerberry.<ref name="TimesEngland2">{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article6992866.ece | title=Noisy tribute for Peter Moore, London's town crier | work=The Times | date=18 January 2010 | accessdate=16 May 2011 | author=Bannerman, Lucy}}</ref> Later, impresario [[Bernard Delfont]] swore him in as a town crier in the [[Piccadilly Circus]]. He was called on by [[Ken Livingstone]], Leader of the [[Greater London Council]], to promote parades in the [[South Bank]].<ref name="TimesEngland" />
Peter spent 31 years as the official Town Crier of London,<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/6907934/Londons-town-crier-of-31-years-dies.html | title=London's town crier of 31 years dies | work=The Telegraph | date=29 December 2009 | accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref> and was also the town crier to the mayor of London, the Greater London Authority, the city of Westminster and the London borough of Merton. Moore announced the 1982 birth of [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William of Wales]] outside the gates of [[Buckingham Palace]].<ref name="Blog">{{cite web | url=http://www.blogofdeath.com/archives/001666.html | title=Peter Moore | publisher=The Blog of Death | date=2 January 2010 | accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref>
Moore was a well-known figure in London, often seen at various locations such as [[Covent Garden]], [[Trafalgar Square]], [[The Tower of London]], [[Parliament Square]], or [[Piccadilly Circus]]. Peter had a deep love and fondness of London, often shown when quoting [[Dr Samuel Johnson]], ''"When a man is tired of London, he is tired of life, for in London there is all that life can afford."''<ref name="pmoore">{{cite web | url=http://www.users.globalnet.co.uk/~webpage/pmoore/docs1.4/index.html | title=Town Crier London, UK, England, Great Britain | publisher=GlobalNet | accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref>
===Stolen bell=== In December 2001, while assisting tourists with directions to [[10 Downing Street]], Moore's bell was stolen when he put it on the ground. The bell was replaced with one from the [[Whitechapel Bell Foundry]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.london-se1.co.uk/news/view/87 | title=Town Crier’s bell stolen on South Bank | publisher=London SE1 | date=3 December 2001 | accessdate=17 May 2011}}</ref> makers also of the American [[Liberty Bell]].<ref name="pmoore"/>
==Death== Moore died of a heart attack on 20 December 2009, at his home in Wandsworth, South London, aged 70.<ref name="TimesEngland" /> "He had been told that his heart was very weak but he never gave up doing his town crying," his former partner Maxine Howard said. "Peter was a trooper, a workaholic. He was a people person. He just adored London."<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/peter-moore-former-london-town-crier-1857787.html, January 9, 2018</ref> On 18 January 2010, friends, family, and colleagues celebrated Moore at St. George’s Cathedral in Southwark, Central London. At the requiem, held the same day, fellow town criers and colleagues from across England paid tribute to him.<ref name="TimesEngland2" /> Later, at the London New Year's Day Parade, his presence was replaced with a shouted "welcome", pre-recorded by him before his death. He is survived by his wife, Maxine Howard, and his son Jamie, who accepted a lifetime achievement award at the parade, in place of his father.<ref name="TimesEngland" />
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Moore, Peter}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Town criers]] [[Category:People from Walsall]]

revision.text:
[[File:Red Fox James at White House.png|thumb|right|200px|Red Fox James at the White House, 1915]]
==Rev. Red Fox James==
'''Rev. Red Fox James PH D. D. D.<ref>https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/23317308/</ref>''', also known as '''Red Fox Skiuhushu''', was a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], presumed to be from the [[Blackfoot|Blackfoot Tribe of Montana]]. He is best known for riding over 4,000 miles on horseback from state to state seeking approval for a day to honor Native Americans. On December 14, 1915, he presented the endorsements of 24 state governments at the [[White House]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianaffairs.gov/DocumentLibrary/HeritageMonth/index.htm|title=Indian Affairs - National American Indian & Alaska Native Heritage Month History|publisher=}}</ref>
Red Fox was an active member of the [[Society of American Indians]] and was the Most High Chief of the Tipi Order of America. He was also the first to organize the Indian Boy Scouts in America, at the United States Indian School in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]].<ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1915-03-04/ed-1/seq-11/#date1=1884&index=0&rows=20&words=Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref name="Letter : 1920 January 5, Red Fox Skiuhushu to Richard Henry Pratt">{{cite web|title=Letter : 1920 January 5, Red Fox Skiuhushu to Richard Henry Pratt|url=http://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/3952330|website=Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library|accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84038095/1914-07-08/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=1884&index=7&rows=20&words=Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-05-05/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=1884&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=9&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2</ref> <ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-07-07/ed-1/seq-14/#date1=1789&sort=relevance&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Rev&searchType=basic&sequence=0&index=8&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=rev+red+fox&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=2</ref>
By 1920, Red Fox was the Head Chief of the American Indian Tepee Christian Mission, a cooperative of the [[American Christian Missionary Society]].<ref name="Letter : 1920 January 5, Red Fox Skiuhushu to Richard Henry Pratt"/><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038411/1919-07-07/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1890&index=4&rows=20&words=Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Skiuhushu&y=14&x=13&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
==Organized The First American Indian Boy Scout Troop== In January of 1915. Organized The First American Indian Boy Scout Troop; Boy Scout Troop 1 Carlisle, Pennsylvania.
<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=pJUFOhyKWpgC&pg=PA42&dq=boy+scout+troop+1++Carlisle,+Pennsylvania.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo3rHUsvDVAhVM6YMKHT2XDX4Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=boy%20scout%20troop%201%20%20Carlisle%2C%20Pennsylvania.&f=true</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84038095/1914-07-08/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=1884&index=7&rows=20&words=Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>https://mowryjournal.com/2013/05/17/red-fox-james/</ref><ref>http://home.epix.net/~landis/charles.html</ref> <ref>https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-07-07/ed-1/seq-14/#date1=1921&index=6&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Rev&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1943&proxtext=rev+red+fox&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
==Support for women's suffrage== Red Fox James was a supporter of giving women the right to vote, because "In the early days, before the white-man came, the Indian women had equal voice in the council, and even was [sic] elected chieftain..."<ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87062055/1916-09-22/ed-1/seq-4/#date1=1884&index=18&rows=20&words=Fo%27x+Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
==New York City College Speech==
On July 4th 1917 Red Fox James gave a speech at New York City College Stadium 25,000 people were present including US Secretary of War [[Newton D. Baker]]. <ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020558/1921-01-09/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1789&index=6&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Rev&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=rev+red+fox&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
=="Adopts" Florence Harding==
In 1920 Red Fox James as "Chief" of The Tipi Order of America presented [[Florence Harding]] with honorary Indian Citizenship and the Indian name "Snow Bird" meaning Worker.<ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042243/1920-07-09/ed-1/seq-3/#date1=1886&index=10&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=Red+Fox+Skiuhushu&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87055779/1920-07-07/ed-1/seq-4/#date1=1886&index=15&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=Red+Fox+Skiuhushu&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86072143/1920-07-08/ed-1/seq-4/#date1=1886&index=19&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=Red+Fox+Skiuhushu&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1920-07-07/ed-1/seq-13/#date1=1789&index=16&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Rev&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=rev+red+fox&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
==Known biographical timeline== * Born about 1884 in [[Blood Indian Reserve No. 148]], Alberta Canada<ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038411/1919-06-25/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1886&index=2&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=Red+Fox+Skiuhushu&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>http://electricindian.50megs.com/redfox2.htm</ref> <ref>https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/23317308/</ref>
* Father Thomas St. James
* Mother Blackfoot Indian Woman
* His cousin and later assistant Pastor Rev Black Hawk was born in 1896. <ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038411/1919-06-25/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1886&index=2&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1925&proxtext=Red+Fox+Skiuhushu&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref>
* 1914 Resident of Waldheim, Montana.<ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89064695/1918-09-05/ed-1/seq-8/#date1=1890&index=5&rows=20&words=Skiuhushu&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Skiuhushu&y=14&x=13&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref> The town changed its name to Bundy when the railroad arrived in 1919 and was disestablished in 1935.<ref>https://www.flickr.com/photos/outlawpete/8543457226</ref><ref>https://www.mapquest.com/us/mt/bundy-283428059</ref> * First involved with Boy Scouts in 1914. * In January of 1915. Organized The First American Indian Boy Scout Troop; Boy Scout Troop 1 Carlisle, Pennsylvania <ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=pJUFOhyKWpgC&pg=PA42&dq=boy+scout+troop+1++Carlisle,+Pennsylvania.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo3rHUsvDVAhVM6YMKHT2XDX4Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=boy%20scout%20troop%201%20%20Carlisle%2C%20Pennsylvania.&f=true</ref><ref>http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84038095/1914-07-08/ed-1/seq-7/#date1=1884&index=7&rows=20&words=Fox+James+Red&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1924&proxtext=Red+Fox+James&y=17&x=8&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref><ref>https://mowryjournal.com/2013/05/17/red-fox-james/</ref><ref>http://home.epix.net/~landis/charles.html</ref> <ref>https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-07-07/ed-1/seq-14/#date1=1921&index=6&rows=20&words=Fox+Red+Rev&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1943&proxtext=rev+red+fox&y=0&x=0&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1</ref> * Ordained a minister in 1915.
* Founded TeePee Order in 1915<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=nuYACtGWDiQC&pg=PA214&lpg=PA214&dq=red+fox+james+boy+scouts&source=bl&ots=m_xeOwXOry&sig=1J5cE4QPZtvU1t0px-sgpdKYLSg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=heiCUaq4LeamiQKJ84CABA#v=onepage&q=red%20fox%20james%20boy%20scouts&f=true</ref>
* 1918 Founded The American Indian Christian Teepee Mission on the Yakima Indian Reservation in Washington State. <ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=KzSHDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=american+indian+christian+teepee+mission&source=bl&ots=jyjOSSQVEZ&sig=jc8dFqYnhm2OPECaeBn4Zdycmvs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSrtH2tu_VAhUCMyYKHe5LAK4Q6AEITzAM#v=onepage&q=american%20indian%20christian%20teepee%20mission&f=false</ref>
* Son Dr. Vincent Red Fox James, Jr<ref>https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/23317308/</ref>
* Death date unknown ( after 1946 )<ref>https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/23317308/</ref>
==See also== * [[Native American Day]] * [[Native American Indian Heritage Month]]

[[File:PSM V42 D596 Robert Hare.jpg|right|thumb|Robert Hare]]
'''Robert Hare''' (January 17, 1781 – May 15, 1858) was an early [[United States|American]] [[chemistry|chemist]].<ref>{{Cite PSM|wstitle=Sketch of Robert Hare|month-and-year=March 1893|volume=42|pages=695-699|noicon=yes}}</ref>
==Biography==
Hare was born in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] on January 17, 1781. He developed and experimented with the [[oxy-hydrogen]] [[blowpipe (tool)|blowpipe]], with [[Edward Daniel Clarke]] of [[Oxford]], shortly after 1800. He married Harriett Clark and had six children. He was a professor at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] between 1810 and 1812 and between 1818 and 1847. By the 1820s, Hare had developed the "galvanic deflagrator", a type of voltaic [[battery (electricity)|battery]] having large plates used for producing rapid and powerful [[combustion]].<ref name="Kneeland 2008">Kneeland, Timothy W. (2008). ''Robert Hare: Politics, Science, and Spiritualism in the Early Republic''. The Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography. Vol. 132, No. 3. pp. 245-260.</ref> He was elected an Associate Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1824.<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter H|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterH.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=September 9, 2016}}</ref>
Hare died in Philadelphia on May 15, 1858.<ref>Jordan, John W. (1978). ''Colonial And Revolutionary Families Of Pennsylvania''. Genealogical Publishing Company. pp. 130-131. {{ISBN|0-8063-0811-7}}</ref>
==Spiritualism== [[File:Robert Hare Apparatus.png|thumb|left|Apparatus that Hare used to test mediums.]] In 1853, Hare conducted experiments with [[mediumship|mediums]]. A year later Hare had converted to [[Spiritualism]] and wrote several books that made him very famous in the United States as a Spiritualist.<ref>Hoover, Stephanie. (2013). ''Philadelphia Spiritualism and the Curious Case of Katie King''. The History Press. p. 25. {{ISBN|978-1-62619-153-2}}</ref> He published a book entitled ''Experimental Investigation of the Spirit Manifestations'' (1855). His work was criticized by scientists but was welcomed with enthusiasm by Spiritualists.<ref>Smith-Dalton, Maggi. (2012). ''A History of Spiritualism and the Occult in Salem: The Rise of Witch City''. The History Press. p. 91-92. {{ISBN|978-1-60949-551-0}}</ref>
One of his experiments utilized a board and spring balance, the other involved the movement of a [[table (furniture)|table]] at which a medium sat caused a pointer to indicate letters on a wheel. According to the psychical researcher [[Frank Podmore]] it would have been easy for the medium to move the table with their knees or other parts of the body but "Hare does not seem to have realized the possibility of fraud of this kind."<ref>[[Frank Podmore|Podmore, Frank]]. (1897). ''Studies in Psychical Research''. G. P. Putnam's Sons. pp. 48-49</ref> Podmore also wrote that "the machinery, indeed, was not ill-devised, but its use did not dispense with the necessity for close and continuous observation of the human agent; and there is no evidence that Hare recognized this necessity, or took any steps to guard against trickery."<ref>[[Frank Podmore|Podmore, Frank]]. (1902). ''Modern Spiritualism: A History and a Criticism''. Methuen Publishing. pp. 234-235</ref>
Science writer [[Terence Hines]] has written:
{{quote|What of the scientists such as Hare and Wallace, who were convinced by what they saw at seances? Were they incompetent scientists, dupes, or just plain gullible? The answer is none of the above. They had simply ventured out of their own area of expertise—an often fatal mistake. They assumed, as did their critics in the scientific community, that if one is a good observer in the laboratory, one is also qualified to observe in the seance. This is simply not true. Mediums were known to cheat, using the magicians’ tricks of sleight of hand and distraction. Magic is a skilled trade requiring years of experience and practice. The training of a chemist, physicist, or psychologist confers no ability to spot magicians’ tricks. To detect such cheating requires a magician.<ref>[[Terence Hines|Hines, Terence]]. (2003). ''Pseudoscience and the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. p. 52. {{ISBN|1-57392-979-4}}</ref>}}
Historian Timothy Kneeland has argued that Hare's interest in Spiritualism was consistent with political and social beliefs that he held throughout his career. His book ''Experimental Investigation of the Spirit Manifestations'' (1855) promoted the restoration of [[social order]] based on principles of [[republicanism]].<ref name="Kneeland 2008"/>
==Publications==
Hare was a prolific writer, writing about hundred and fifty articles in the [[American Journal of Science]]. Among his other publications, there are:
* ''A Brief View of the Policy and Resources of the United States'' (1810); * ''Chemical Apparatus and Manipulations'' (1836); * ''Compendium of the Course of Chemical Instruction in the Medical Department of the University of Pennsylvania'' (1840); * ''Memoir on the Explosiveness of Niter'' (1850); *[https://archive.org/stream/experimentalinv00hare#page/n5/mode/2up ''Experimental Investigation of the Spirit Manifestations''] (1855); * ''Spiritualism Scientifically Demonstrated'' (1855).
Hare also wrote two novels: * ''Standish the Puritan: A Tale of the American Revolution'' (1850) * ''Overing: or, The heir of Wycherly. A Historical Romance'' (1852)
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== {{wikisource|A History of the Medical Department of the University of Pennsylvania/Chapter XIV}} *[http://resource.nlm.nih.gov/55620180R Bache, Franklin. ''Robert Hare, M.D.'', (1858).] From the Digital Collections of the [[National Library of Medicine]]. *Isaacs, Ernest Joseph (1957). ''A History of Spiritualism: The Beginnings, 1845-1855''. University of Wisconsin. *Lord, John (1856). ''Modern Spiritualism, Scientifically Demonstrated to be a Mendacious Humbug, in a Series of Letters to Professor Robert Hare, Author of a Book Entitled Spiritualism Scientifically Demonstrated''. Brown Thurston. * {{cite book | author = Smith, Edgar Fahs | title = The Life of Robert Hare: An American Chemist (1781-1858) | year = 1917 |publisher = J. P. Lippincott Company | location = London}}
{{Spiritualism and spiritism}} {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
'''Ronald John Henry Kaulback''' (23 July 1909 – 1995) was a British explorer, botanist and geographer. He was the son of Colonel H. A. Kaulback and had a younger brother Roy (known as Bill).<ref>Kaulback, Ronald (1934). ''Tibetan Trek''. London: Hodder & Stoughton. pp. 13-14.</ref> After studying at the [[University of Cambridge]] and learning surveying at the Royal Geographical Society he accompanied [[Frank Kingdon-Ward]] on an expedition to Tibet. For political reasons Kaulbach was forbidden to continue on the second part of that journey. So he, Brooks Carrington and some others set out on a route by [[Fort Hertz]] and Burma which included crossing the [[Diphuk La]] and after travelling at the worst season reached Fort Hertz.<ref>Kingdon-Ward F (1934). "Introduction". '''''In'':''' Kaulback R (1934). ''Tibetan Trek''. London: Hodder & Stoughton; pp. 9-11.</ref> He travelled in [[Burma]], [[Nepal]] and [[Tibet]].<ref>[http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19350117.2.25.aspx "New Expedition to Tibet"]. ''[[The Straits Times]]''. 17 January 1935. p. 6. Accessed 12 May 2010.</ref>
Kaulback wrote in defence of the possible existence of the [[Yeti]],<ref>[[Willy Ley|Ley, Willy]] (1962). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xboLAQAAIAAJ Exotic Zoology]''. p. 79.</ref> having seen what he took to be large footprints while attempting to locate the source of the [[Salween River]].<ref>[[Ivan T. Sanderson|Sanderson, Ivan T.]] (1961). ''Abominable Snowmen''. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gbwfRq5-5YAC&lpg=RA1-PA446&dq=%22Ronald%20Kaulbach%22&lr&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is&as_brr=3&pg=RA1-PA261#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 261].</ref>
==Legacy== Kaulbach is commemorated in the scientific name of a species of Asian pit viper, ''[[Trimeresurus kaulbacki|Protobothrops kaulbacki]]''.<ref>Beolens, Bo; Watkins, Michael; Grayson, Michael (2011). ''The Eponym Dictionary of Reptiles''. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. xiii + 296 pp. {{ISBN|978-1-4214-0135-5}}. ("Kaulback", p. 138).</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person.php?LinkID=mp55933 Portraits of Ronald Kaulback] at the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)]]. *[http://www.ornaverum.org/family/kaulback-ronald.html Further biographical notes] and a more detailed account of Kaulback's life and accomplishments.
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}}

{{UK-explorer-stub}}

The '''Roy G. Neville Prize in Bibliography or Biography''' is a biennial award given by the [[Science History Institute]] (formerly the Chemical Heritage Foundation) to recognize a biographical work in the field of chemistry or molecular science.<ref name=CHF/> The Roy G. Neville Prize was established in 2006 and named to honor scientist and book collector Roy G. Neville. Neville founded Engineering and Technical Consultants, Redwood City, California, in 1973. He also assembled one of the world's largest collections of rare books in the field of science and technology. The Neville collection, including over 6,000 titles from the late 15th century to the early 20th century, was acquired by the Chemical Heritage Foundation (now the Science History Institute) in 2004.<ref name="Catalogue">{{cite book|last1=Neville|first1=Roy G.|title=The Roy G. Neville Historical Chemical Library: An Annotated Catalogue of Printed Books on Alchemy|date=2006|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|location=Philadelphia, Penn|isbn=9780941901406}}</ref><ref name="Greenberg">{{cite book|last1=Greenberg|first1=Arthur|title=From alchemy to chemistry in picture and story|date=2006|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, NJ|isbn=978-0471751540|page=xxiii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dG5ReuR4GqoC&pg=PR23|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Sanderson">{{cite web|last1=Sanderson|first1=Katharine|title=Chemical bounty in the bargain basement|url=http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/Issues/2004/June/bargain.asp|website=Royal Society of Chemistry|accessdate=18 May 2016|date=2004}}</ref>
==Recipients== The following people have received the Neville Award:<ref name="CHF">{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/roy-g-neville-prize|title= Roy G. Neville Prize in Bibliography or Biography|publisher= Science History Institute|accessdate = 1 February 2018}}</ref>
*2017, John C. Powers for ''Inventing Chemistry: Herman Boerhaave and the Reform of the Chemical Arts''<ref name="VCU">{{cite news|title=Faculty and Staff Features for August 2017|url=https://news.vcu.edu/article/Faculty_and_Staff_Features_for_August_2017|accessdate=22 October 2017|work=VCU News|date=August 31, 2017}}</ref> *2016 Melvyn Usselman, for ''Pure Intelligence: The Life of William Hyde Wollaston'' *2013 [[Mary Jo Nye]], for ''Michael Polanyi and His Generation: Origins of the Social Construction of Science''<ref name="CHF"/> *2011 [[Michael Hunter (historian)|Michael Hunter]], for ''Boyle: Between God and Science''<ref name="Birkbeck">{{cite web|title=Professor Michael Hunter|url=http://www.bbk.ac.uk/about-us/fellows/michael-hunter|website=Birkbeck University of London|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Committee|url=http://isih.history.ox.ac.uk/?page_id=33|website=International Society for Intellectual History|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> *2009 William H. Brock, for ''William Crookes (1832–1919) and the Commercialization of Science''<ref name="Leicester">{{cite web|title=Emeritus Professor of History of Science wins accolade International Prize for Professor Bill Brock|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/ebulletin-archive/ebulletin/people/honours-and-awards/2000-2009/2009/09/nparticle.2009-09-15.html|website=University of Leicester|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> *2007 Michael D. Gordin, for ''A Well-Ordered Thing: Dmitrii Mendeleev and the Shadow of the Periodic Table''<ref name="PENNGordin">{{cite web|title=Speaking Utopian|url=https://www.phf.upenn.edu/events/speaking-utopian|website=University of Pennsylvania|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Guggenheim">{{cite web|title=Michael Gordin|url=http://www.gf.org/fellows/all-fellows/michael-gordin/|website=Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> *2006 Robert E. Schofield, for ''The Enlightened Joseph Priestley: A Study of His Life and Works from 1773 to 1804''<ref name="Gussman">{{cite journal|last1=Gussman|first1=Neil|title=Biography of Joseph Priestley Receives First Neville Prize|journal=Chemical Heritage Magazine|date=2006|volume=24|issue=4|page=21|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/23488360/biography-joseph-priestley-receives-first-neville-prize|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="IAS">{{cite web|title=Robert Edwin Schofield|url=https://www.ias.edu/scholars/robert-edwin-schofield|website=Institute for Advanced Study|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of prizes, medals and awards]] *[[List of prizes named after people]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = [[General]] | name = Sunith Francis Rodrigues | honorific_suffix = [[Param Vishisht Seva Medal|PVSM]], [[Vishisht Seva Medal|VSM]] | image = File:General Sunith Francis Rodrigues.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1933|09|19}} | birth_place = [[Mumbai]] | death_date = | death_place = | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegiance = {{flag|India}} | branch = {{army|India}} | serviceyears = 1952-1993 | rank = [[File:General of the Indian Army.svg|15px]] [[General officer|General]] | servicenumber = IC-6119{{cite news |title=Part I-Section 4: Ministry of Defence (Army Branch) |page=295 |date=1 April 1978 |website= |publisher=The Gazette of India}} | unit = [[File:Artillery_Insignia.gif|20px]] [[Regiment of Artillery (India)|Regiment of Artillery]] | commands = [[File:IA_Western_Command.jpg|20px]] [[Western Command (India)|Western Army]]
[[File:IA_Central_Command.jpg|20px]] [[Central Command (India)|Central Army]]
Director General Military Training (DGMT) | battles = | battles_label = | awards = [[File:Param Vishisht Seva Medal ribbon.svg|25px]][[Param Vishisht Seva Medal]]
[[File:Vishisht Seva Medal ribbon.svg|25px]][[Vishisht Seva Medal]] | memorials = | spouse = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} [[General]] '''Sunith Francis Rodrigues''', [[Param Vishisht Seva Medal|PVSM]], [[Vishisht Seva Medal|VSM]] (born 19 September 1933) is a retired Indian army officer who was [[Chief of the Army Staff (India)|Chief of the Army Staff]] of the [[Indian Army]]http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?262249http://www.openthemagazine.com/article/nation/the-colonel-who-got-us-siachen from 1990 to 1993 and [[List of governors of Punjab (India)|Governor]] of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] from 2004 to 2010. During his years as Governor of Punjab, he generally received a positive response from the [[Punjabi press (India)|Punjabi press]] and the [[Punjabi people]] accepted him as one of their own due to his strong campaigning for Punjabi interests in India. ==Education== Born in Bombay in 1933, he was educated at St. Xaviers High School in Bombay. ==Military service== He joined the [[Joint Services Wing]] of the [[Indian Military Academy]] in 1949 and was commissioned in December 1952 into Regiment of [[Artillery]]. After commanding several field and self-proppelled artillery units he applied of pilot training in the [[Air Observation Post]] of the Artillery in 1964 and qualified as an artillery aviation pilot. Between 1964 and 1969, he logged more than 158 flying hours on observation aircraft and helicopters, including 65 hours of combat flying during the 1965 war in which his unit logged on more than 56 precision artillery fire to effect on enemy formations. He attended the [[Defence Services Staff College]] and took over as GSOII operations in [[XXXIII Corps (India)|XXXIII Corps]] HQ in 1971. In 1972, after the war with [[Pakistan]], he was awarded the [[Vishisht Seva Medal|VSM]] for distinguished service. He later served as a GSOI operations of a division from 1973 to 1975. He commanded a mountain infantry brigade in a high altitude sector from 1975 to 1977 then attended the 1978 course at [[Royal College of Defence Studies]] in the [[UK]]. He was Chief Instructor at Defence Services Staff College from 1979 to November 1981, then took over the command of a division in a high altitude area. In 1982, he was awarded the master's degree in Defence Studies, was the Chief of Staff of a Corps from 1983 to September 1985 then took over as Director General Military Training. He was GOC of a corps in the Northern Sector in 1986. He was Vice Chief of Army Staff from November 1987 to April 1989 and then [[General Officer Commanding|GOC-in-C]] of Central Command from April 1989 to October 1989. He then took over Western Command from 1 November 1989 to 30 June 1990 and was the Chief of Army Staff from 1990 to 1993. He retired on 30 June 1993 after nearly 41 years of service. General Rodrigues was known among his compatriots as a thinker and a strategist. ==Public service== After his retirement he was Director of the International Centre, [[Goa]] for nearly six years. He served two terms on the National Security Advisory Board. Since his retirement, he has been engaged in social and literary pursuits and has also delivered talks on strategic issues. He takes a keen interest in education and empowering children to achieve their potential. He was on the Executive Council of [[Goa University]] for seven years and on the Managing Committee of the Goa Chamber of Commerce. He is also a long-standing Member of the Goa Planning Board and on the Board of Governors of the Goa Institute of Management. ===Governor of Punjab=== He was appointed as Governor of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] and Administrator of the [[Union Territory]] of [[Chandigarh]] on 8 November 2004, and he was sworn into office on 16 November 2004. He was succeeded by [[Shivraj Patil]] on 22 January 2010.{{cite news |title=Shiv Raj Patil is 33rd Governor of Punjab |author= |newspaper=Punjab Newsline Network |date=22 January 2010 |url=http://www.punjabnewsline.com/content/shiv-raj-patil-33rd-governor-punjab }} == References == {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box | before = [[Vishwa Nath Sharma]]|title = [[Chief of Army Staff of the Indian Army|Chief of Army Staff]] | years = 1990–1993 | after = [[B. C. Joshi|Bipin Chandra Joshi]]}} {{Succession box | title = [[Vice Chief of Army Staff (India)|Vice Chief of Army Staff]] | years = 1 November 1987 - 20 April 1989 | before = J K Puri | after = V K Sood }} {{Succession box | title = General Officer Commanding-in-Chief [[Western Command (India)|Western Command]] | years = 1 November 1989 - 30 June 1990 | before = V K Nayak | after = G S Grewal }} {{s-end}} {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{succession box | before=[[Akhlaqur Rahman Kidwai]] | title=[[List of Governors of Punjab (India)|Governor of Punjab]] | years = 2004–2010 | after = [[Shivraj Patil]]}} {{s-end}} {{Chief of the Army Staff India}} {{PunjabGovernors}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rodrigues, Sunith Francis}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chiefs of Army Staff (India)]] [[Category:Vice Chiefs of Army Staff (India)]] [[Category:Goan Catholics]] [[Category:Military personnel from Mumbai]] [[Category:Konkani people]] [[Category:Governors of Punjab, India]] [[Category:Recipients of the Param Vishisht Seva Medal]] [[Category:Indian Roman Catholics]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{about|the Turkish law|the general concept|Surname law}} The '''Surname Law''' ({{lang-tr|Soyadı Kanunu}}) of the [[Republic of Turkey]] was adopted on June 21, 1934.<ref>[http://www.perge.gov.tr/EN/BelgeGoster.aspx?17A16AE30572D313E603BF9486D4371DF01B9CC4F1C001E7 1934 in history], Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism.</ref> The law requires all citizens of Turkey to adopt the use of hereditary, fixed, [[surname]]s. Much of the population, particularly in the cities as well as Turkey's [[Christian]] and [[Jewish]] citizens, already had surnames, and all families had names by which they were known locally. The Surname Law of 1934 enforced not only the use of official surnames but also stipulated that citizens choose [[Turkish language|Turkish]] names. Until it was repealed in 2013 in Turkey the eldest male was the head of household and the law appointed him to choose the surname. However in his absence, death or mental incapacitation the wife would do so.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://repository.upenn.edu/dissertations/AAI3125908/|title = The Social Life of the State's Fantasy: Memories and Documents on Turkey's Surname Law of 1934|date = 2004|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Turkoz|first = Meltem}}</ref>
This law was modeled after a 1926 Fascist [[Italianization]] law 'restoring' German, Slovene and Croat surnames to their 'original Italian form'.<ref>Regio decreto legge 10 Gennaio 1926, n. 17: Restituzione in forma italiana dei cognomi delle famiglie della provincia di Trento</ref><ref>Mezulić, Hrvoje; R. Jelić (2005) Fascism, baptiser and scorcher (O Talijanskoj upravi u Istri i Dalmaciji 1918-1943.: nasilno potalijančivanje prezimena, imena i mjesta), Dom i svijet, Zagreb, {{ISBN|953-238-012-4}}</ref>
Muslims in the Ottoman Empire carried [[title]]s such as “[[Pasha]]”, “[[Hoca]]”, “[[Bey]]”, “[[Khanum|Hanım]]”, “[[Efendi]]”, etc. These titles either defined their formal profession (such as Pasha, Hoca, etc.) or their informal status within the society (such as Bey, Hanım, Efendi, etc.). Ottoman [[prime minister]]s (Sadrazam/Vezir-î Azam or [[Grand Vizier]]), ministers (Nazır/Vezir or [[Vizier]]) and other high-ranking [[civil servant]]s also carried the title Pasha. Retired generals/admirals or high-ranking civil servants continued to carry this title in civilian life. A “Pasha” did not become a “Bey” after retiring from active military or political service.
The articles of the Soy Adı Kanunu<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.nvi.gov.tr/Files/File/Mevzuat/Nufus_Mevzuati/Kanun/pdf/soyadi_kanunu.pdf|title =Soy Adı Kanunu|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20170107165807/http://www.nvi.gov.tr/Files/File/Mevzuat/Nufus_Mevzuati/Kanun/pdf/soyadi_kanunu.pdf|archivedate =2017-01-07|df =}}</ref> stipulated that: # All Turks must bear their surnames in addition to their proper name; #The surname must follow the proper name in signing, speaking and writing; #Names may not relate to military rank and civil officialdom; to tribes, foreign races or ethnicities; nor may they be offensive or ridiculous. The use of “historical names” without the proper genealogical evidence were also forbidden.
The surname law specifically forbade certain surnames that contained connotations of foreign cultures, nations, tribes, and religions.<ref name="Basak">{{cite book|last=İnce|first=Başak|title=Citizenship and identity in Turkey : from Atatürk's republic to the present day|publisher=I.B. Tauris|location=London|isbn=9781780760261}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Aslan|first=Senem|title=Incoherent State: The Controversy over Kurdish Naming in Turkey|url=http://ejts.revues.org/index4142.html|publisher=European Journal of Turkish Studies|accessdate=16 January 2013|quote=the Surname Law was meant to foster a sense of Turkishness within society and prohibited surnames that were related to foreign ethnicities and nations}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Suny |editor-first=Ronald Grigor |title=A question of genocide : Armenians, and Turks at the end of the Ottoman Empire |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=9780195393743 |editor2=Goçek, Fatma Müge |editor3=Naimark, Norman M.}}</ref><ref name="Citizenship and Minorities: A Historical Overview of Turkey’s Jewish Minority">{{cite journal|last=Toktas|first=Sule|title=Citizenship and Minorities: A Historical Overview of Turkey’s Jewish Minority|journal=Journal of Historical Sociology|year=2005|volume=18|issue=4|url=https://www.academia.edu/761586/Citizenship_and_minorities_a_historical_overview_of_Turkeys_Jewish_minority|accessdate=7 January 2013}}</ref> New surnames had to be taken from the Turkish language. The surname could be used with the {{nbh}}''oğlu'' ending, and it was forbidden to use Armenian endings such as {{nbh}}''ian'' or {{nbh}}''yan'', Slavic endings such as {{nbh}}''of'' (or {{nbh}}''ov''), {{nbh}}''vich'', {{nbh}}''ic'', Greek endings such as {{nbh}}''is'', {{nbh}}''dis'', {{nbh}}''pulos'', {{nbh}}''aki'', Persian endings such as {{nbh}}''zade'', and Arab endings such as {{nbh}}''mahdumu'', {{nbh}}''veled'', and {{nbh}}''bin'', "referring to other ethnicities or taken from another language." For example, names such as ''Arnavutoğlu'' (the Albanian’s son) or ''Kürtoğlu'' (the Kurd’s son), could not be used. Names of clans or tribes could not be used, or re-used.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.nvi.gov.tr/Files/File/Mevzuat/Nufus_Mevzuati/Tuzukler/pdf/soyadi_nizamnamesi.pdf|title =Soy Adı Nizamnamesi|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20151123200758/http://www.nvi.gov.tr/Files/File/Mevzuat/Nufus_Mevzuati/Tuzukler/pdf/soyadi_nizamnamesi.pdf|archivedate =2015-11-23|df =}}</ref> Additionally, names could not be duplicated in the same district, and, in case of any dispute, the family that registered first got the right to keep the claimed name.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00263200701568253|title = Surname narratives and the state–society boundary: Memories of Turkey's family name law of 1934|last = Turkoz|first = Meltem|date = 2007|journal = Middle Eastern Studies |volume=43 |issue=6 |pages=|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
As a result, many [[Greeks in Turkey|Greeks]], [[Bulgarians in Turkey|Bulgarians]], [[Albanians in Turkey|Albanians]], [[Bosniaks in Turkey|Bosniaks]], [[Jews in Turkey|Jews]], [[Arabs in Turkey|Arabs]], [[Armenians in Turkey|Armenians]], [[Assyrians in Turkey|Assyrians]], [[Georgians in Turkey|Georgians]] and [[Kurds in Turkey|Kurds]] were and are still forced to adopt last names of a more Turkish rendition,<ref name="Basak" /> sometimes directly translating their original surnames, or otherwise just replacing markers such as [[Pontic Greeks|Pontic Greek]] “{{nbh}}ides” (son of) with Turkish “{{nbh}}oğlu” ([[Elia Kazan|Kazantzoglou]], [[Konstantinos Mitroglou|Mitroglou]], [[Patrick Mouratoglou|Mouratoglou]], etc.).
==See also== *[[List of Ottoman titles and appellations]] *[[Turkification]] *[[Italianization]]
==References== {{reflist}}
