{{For|the play by [[Sophocles]] by this title|Tereus (play)}} [[File:Tereo.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]]: ''Tereus Confronted with the Head of his Son Itys'', 1636–38]] In [[Greek mythology]], '''Tereus''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|t|ɛ|r|i|ə|s|,_|ˈ|t|ɪər|j|uː|s}}; [[Ancient Greek]]: Τηρεύς means "watcher"<ref>[[Robert Graves]]. ''[[The Greek Myths]] (1960)''</ref>) was a [[Thracians|Thracian]] king,<ref name=T>[[Thucydides]]: ''[[History of the Peloponnesian War]]'' [[s:History of the Peloponnesian War/Book 2#2:29|2:29]]</ref><ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0022&layout=&loc=3.14.8 3.14.8]</ref> the son of [[Ares]] and the naiad [[Bistonis]]. He was the brother of [[Dryas of Calydon|Dryas]]. Tereus was the husband of the Athenian princess [[Procne]] and the father of [[Itys]].
== Mythology == When Tereus desired his wife's sister, [[Philomela]], he came to Athens to his father-in-law Pandion to ask for his other daughter in marriage, stating that Procne had died. Pandion granted him the favour, and sent Philomela and guards along with her. But Tereus threw the guards into the sea, and finding Philomela on a mountain, forced himself upon her. He then cut her tongue out and held her captive so she could never tell anyone. After he returned to Thrace, Tereus gave Philomela to King [[Lynceus (mythology)|Lynceus]] and told his wife that her sister had died. Philomela wove letters in a [[tapestry]] depicting Tereus's crime and sent it secretly to Procne. Lynceus' wife [[Lathusa]] who was a friend of Procne, at once sent the concubine (Philomela) to her.
When Procne recognized her sister and knew the impious deed of Tereus, the two planned to return the favour to the king. Meanwhile it was revealed to Tereus by prodigies that death by a relative's hand was coming to his son Itys. When he heard this, thinking that his brother Dryas was plotting his son's death, he killed the innocent man. Procne, however, killed her son Itys by Tereus, served his flesh in a meal at his father's table in revenge, and fled with her sister.
When Tereus learned what the crime she had done, he pursued the sisters and tried to kill them but all three were changed by the [[Twelve Olympians|Olympian Gods]] into birds out of pity: Tereus became a [[hoopoe]] or a hawk; Procne became the [[swallow]] whose song is a song of mourning for the loss of her child; Philomela became the [[nightingale]]. Incidentally, the female nightingale has no song. ([[Hyginus]], ''Fabulae'', 45).
== Other usage == Tereus was also a common given name among Thracians.<ref name=T />
The [[Athens|Attic]] playwrights [[Sophocles]] and [[Philocles]] both wrote plays entitled ''[[Tereus (play)|Tereus]]'' on the subject of the story of Tereus.<ref>{{cite book|title=Word and Image in Ancient Greece|editor1=Rutter, N.K.|editor2=Sparkes, B.A.|author=March, J.|chapter=Vases and Tragic Drama|pages=121–123|year=2000|publisher=University of Edinburgh|isbn=978-0-7486-1405-9}}</ref>
[[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] refers to Tereus in ''[[Titus Andronicus]]'', after Chiron and Demetrius have raped Lavinia and cut out her tongue and also both her hands. He also makes reference to Tereus in "[[Cymbeline]]", when Iachimo spies upon the sleeping Imogen to gather false evidence so he can persuade Posthumus he has seduced her.
==Modern adaptations== *''[[The Love of the Nightingale]]'', play by [[Timberlake Wertenbaker]] *''[[The Love of the Nightingale (opera)|The Love of the Nightingale]]'', [[opera]] by [[Richard Mills (composer)|Richard Mills]] to a [[libretto]] from the above play
==References== <references />
==External links== *[https://archive.org/details/LustsDominiontereus ''The New Tereus'' by Robert Lalonde]
{{Authority control}}

{{Refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox TV channel | name = The Biography Channel | logofile = The Biography Channel.svg | logosize = 200px | slogan = True Story | launch = 1 October 2000 | closed date = 4 November 2013 | share = 0.1% | share as of = November 2012 | share source = [http://www.barb.co.uk/viewing/monthly-total-viewing-summary?_s=4 BARB] | owner = A+E Networks UK ([[A&E Networks]]/[[Sky plc]]) | former names = | replaced by names = [[Lifetime (UK and Ireland)|Lifetime]] | timeshift names = | sister names = [[Crime & Investigation Network (Europe)|Crime & Investigation Network]]
[[History (European TV channel)|History]]
[[H2 (TV channel)|H2]] }} '''The Biography Channel''' (also known as '''Bio.''') was an [[English speaking]] general entertainment channel available in some European countries. The channel was launched on 1 October 2000 by a joint-venture between [[A&E Networks|A+E Networks]] and [[Sky UK|British Sky Broadcasting]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. It later became available in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], the [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]]. The channel's programming, as the name suggests, is made up of the biographies of famous people, including bands, politicians and criminals. The channel ceased broadcasting at 6am on 4 November 2013 and was replaced by [[Lifetime (UK and Ireland)|Lifetime]]. ==Availability== In the United Kingdom the channel was available on [[Sky UK|Sky]], [[Smallworld Cable]] and [[Virgin Media]]. In Ireland it was available on [[Sky Ireland|Sky]] and [[UPC Ireland]]. In Belgium it was available on [[Telenet (Belgium)|Telenet]]. ==Bio. HD== A [[high-definition television|high definition]] version launched on [[Sky (UK and Ireland)|Sky]] on 5 November 2008,{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2008/10/14/sky-to-launch-aetns-crime-and-investigation-hd-bio-hd-on-nove/|title=Sky to launch AETN's Crime and Investigation HD / Bio HD on November 5th|publisher=Engadget|date=14 October 2008}} it was also available on UPC Ireland from October 2009. Bio. HD operated on a separate schedule to the standard definition channel and timeshared with [[Crime & Investigation Network (Europe)|CI HD]].{{cite web|url=http://www.skyuser.co.uk/skyinfo/even_more_hd_channels_on_their_way_to_you.html|title=Even more HD channels on their way to you|publisher=Sky User|date=13 October 2008}} The channel closed on 3 July 2012 to allow CI HD to broadcast 24 hours a day.{{cite web|url=http://www.entertainment-iuk.com/2012/07/03/crime-hd-changes-and-bio-hd-removed/|title=Crime HD changes and The Biography Channel HD removed|publisher=Entertainment Interactive|date=3 July 2012}} ==See also== * [[FYI (U.S. TV channel)]] * [[The Biography Channel (Canada)]] * [[Bio (Australian TV channel)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk}} {{A+E Networks}} {{BSkyB}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Biography Channel}} [[Category:English-language television stations in the United Kingdom|Biography Channel, The]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2000]] [[Category:Television channels and stations disestablished in 2013]] [[Category:The Biography Channel shows| UK]] [[Category:Sky Ltd television channels]] [[Category:2000 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2013 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct British television channels]] {{UK-tv-channel-stub}}

revision.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Trishneet Arora | image = Trishnet Arora at TEDxGGDSDChandigarh.jpg | image_size = | caption = Arora addressing a [[TED (conference)#TEDx|TEDx]] conference in [[Chandigarh]] | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|2 November 1993}} | birth_place = [[Ludhiana]], [[Punjab, India]] | occupation = CEO of TAC Security | years_active = 2012 - present | website = {{URL|tacsecurity.co.in/leaders.html}} }} '''Trishneet Arora''' (born 2 November 1993){{cite web|title=Official Facebook Page|url=https://www.facebook.com/trishneetaroraofficial/info|accessdate=9 October 2014}} is the founder and CEO of TAC Security, an IT security company. Arora has written books on cyber security, ethical hacking and web defence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/trishneet-arora/|title=Trishneet Arora|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-07-22|language=en}}{{cite news|title=A 20-year-old entrepreneur's success story|work=Rediff.com|date=9 September 2014|url=http://www.rediff.com/money/report/pix-special-20-year-old-entrepreneurs-success-story/20140909.htm|accessdate=22 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=Punjab entrepreneur 20 runs IT security firm|date=8 Sep 2014|work=Business Standard|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/sme/punjab-entrepreneur-20-runs-it-security-firm-114090801211_1.html}}{{cite web|title=The 19yr old cyber crime expert from Ludhiana|work=Yahoo News India|date=18 July 2013|url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/video/19yr-old-cyber-crime-expert-142600983.html}} He was named in [[Forbes 30 Under 30]] 2018 Asia list.{{Cite news|url=http://www.republicworld.com/business-news/india-business/trishneet-arora-in-forbes-30-under-30-asia-2018-list|title=Trishneet Arora in Forbes 30 under 30 Asia 2018 list - Republic World|last=Ltd|first=Interaction One Pvt|work=Republic World|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/trishneet-arora/?list=30under30-asia-enterprise-technology|title=Trishneet Arora|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en}}[[File:Trishneet-Arora-at-Punjabi-Icon-Award.jpg|thumb|Arora at Punjabi Icon Awards alongside [[Virender Sehwag]], [[Ayushmann Khurrana]], [[Malvinder Mohan Singh]], [[Bikram Singh (general)]] and others in Mumbai]] ==Career == Arora founded TAC Security, a cyber security company that provides protection to corporations against network vulnerabilities and data theft.{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/punjab/young-hacker-trains-cops-in-tackling-cyber-crime-cases-in-punjab_1514558.html|title=Young hacker trains cops in tackling cyber-crime cases in Punjab|date=14 Dec 2014|work=ZEE NEWS}}{{cite web|title=TAC Founder - Trishneet Arora|url= http://tacsecurity.co.in/about-founder.html}} Some of his clients are [[Reliance Industries]], [[Central Bureau of Investigation]], [[Punjab Police (India)]] and [[Gujarat Police]].{{cite web|title=A youngster with passion for computers|work=Chandigarh Tribune|date=15 Sep 2012|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2012/20120916/ldh1.htm#10}} He helps the Punjab and Gujarat police in investigating cyber crimes, for which he has conducted training sessions with officials.{{cite web|title=Trishneet Arora featured in London|work=The Weekly Tribune, London(UK)|date=26 Jan 2015|url=http://tacsecurity.co.in/blog/news/tacs-success-story-in-the-weekly-tribune-london-uk/}}{{cite web|title=Young Computer Wizard Roped in as CBI Mentor|work=New Indian Express(Delhi)|date=9 June 2014|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/Young-Computer-Wizard-Roped-in-as-CBI-Mentor/2014/06/09/article2269960.ece}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/offbeat/mumbai-teen-dropped-out-of-school-hes-now-a-cyber-security-expert-1664172|title=Mumbai Teen Dropped Out Of School. At 23, He's A Cyber Security Expert|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2017-11-29}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/india-news/amazing-story-he-failed-8th-standard-now-owns-cyber-security-firm-23-yr-old-millionaire-ethical-hacker-has-clients-like-reliance/943756/|title=Amazing story! He failed 8th standard, now owns cyber security firm; 23-yr-old millionaire ethical hacker has clients like Reliance|date=2017-11-22|work=The Financial Express|access-date=2017-11-29|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://tech.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/technology/meet-the-23-yr-old-cyber-security-entrepreneur-from-chandigarh/56013709|title=Meet the 23 yr old cyber security entrepreneur from Chandigarh - ETtech|last=www.ETtech.com|website=ETtech.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-29}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-heartwarming-ethical-hacker-shares-tale-of-how-his-parents-understood-his-love-for-computers-after-he-failed-class-8-2336521|title=Heartwarming: Ethical hacker shares tale of how his parents understood his love for computers after he failed Class 8 {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|date=2017-02-27|work=dna|access-date=2017-11-29|language=en-US}} Arora's company mainly provides vulnerability assessment and penetration testing services. According to Arora, there has been an increase in the number of attacks against portals of companies.{{cite news|title=Continuous monitoring can check hacking of websites|work=The Financial Express|date=11 Dec 2015|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/tech/cyber-security-continuous-monitoring-can-check-hacking-of-websites/177669/}} == Awards and recognition == {| class="wikitable" revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Missing information|Vættir in Norse myth. The article requires significant verifiable expansion|date=November 2018}} {{Cleanup|date=October 2009}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} }}
The '''Vættir''' (Old Norse; [[Old Norse morphology#Strong nouns|singular '''Vættr''']]) of Norse myth are spirits. The term can be used to refer to the full Norse cosmos of supernatural beings, including the [[Dökkálfar and Ljósálfar|Álfar]] (elves), [[Dwarf (Germanic mythology)|Dvergar]] (dwarves), [[Jötunn|Jötnar]] (giants), and gods (the [[Æsir]] and [[Vanir]]). Vættir can also refer more specifically to [[Landvættir]] ([[nature spirits]]), '''Sjóvættir''' (sea spirits), '''vatnavættir''' (guardians of the specific waters), or '''Húsvættir''' (house spirits.)
==Etymology==
The Old Norse term ''véttr/vættr'' and its English cognate ''wight'' are descended from Proto-Germanic [[wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Germanic/wihtiz|''*wihtiz'']] (thing, creature), from Proto-Indo-European ''*wekti-'' ("object, thing").<ref>http://etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=wight</ref> Vættr and wight normally refer to [[supernatural]] 'being', especially [[landvættr]] (land spirit), but can refer to any creature. The [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] ''vette'' is used much in the same way as the Old Norse ''vættr'', as are the corresponding [[Swedish language|Swedish]] cognate ''vätte'' (dialect form vätter - Old Swedish vætter)<ref>http://runeberg.org/svetym/1267.html</ref> and the [[Danish language|Danish]] ''vætte''. A related form in the Slavic languages can be seen in Old Church Slavonic ''вєшть'', (veštĭ), meaning thing, matter, or subject.
==Viking Age==
[[Landvættir]] (land spirits) are [[chthonic]] guardians of specific grounds, such as wild places or farms. When [[Vikings]] approached land, they reportedly removed their carved [[dragon]] heads from the bows of their [[longship]]s, so as not to frighten and thus provoke the ''landvættir'' to attack, thereby incur bad [[luck]] from them. Icelandic culture continues to celebrate the supernatural protection over the island, and four ''landvættr'' can still be seen in the [[Coat of arms of Iceland|Icelandic coat-of-arms]]: a troll-bull, troll-eagle, dragon, and handsome giant. The troll-animals are actually Jötnar who shapeshifted into the form (and mentality) of an animal, and such animals are supernaturally strong. Even the dragon is generally a troll-snake: compare the Jötunn [[Loki]] whose children include a wolf, a serpent, and a horse.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
==Folklore==
Húsvættir is a collective term for keepers of the household, like the English [[Brownie (folklore)|brownie]] and the Swedish ''[[tomte]]''. The ''tomte'' or ''nisse'' is a solitary vätte, living on the farmstead. He is usually benevolent and helpful, which can not be said about an innately mischievous ''illvätte''. However, a ''nisse'' can cause a lot of damage if he is displeased or angry, including killing of livestock or causing serious accidents.
[[Scandinavian folklore]] features a class of beings similar to the Old Norse ''landvættir''. They are known by many names, although the most common are ''vättar'' in southern [[Sweden]] (singular: vätte), ''[[Vittra (folklore)|vittra]]'' in northern Sweden and ''[[Hulder|huldrefolk]]'' in [[Norway]] (although the singular ''vittra'' and ''huldra'', respectively, refer to a solitary and quite different being).
During the 19th century, [[Peter Christen Asbjørnsen]] and [[Jørgen Moe]] compiled the folk tales among Norwegians, as part of the emotive, nationalistic and anti-rational values of the [[Romanticism|Romantic Era]]. These stories reflected the animistic 'folk belief' that preserved earlier elements deriving from the [[Viking Age]] but strongly influenced by the medieval [[Biblical cosmology]] of Germany, Britain and France. Prominent are stories that reflect later views of the Vættir, usually called the Huldrefolk (from [[Old Norse]] Huldufólk), meaning 'concealed people' and referring to their otherworldliness or their power of invisibility.
The English surname 'Wightman' retains the meaning of the word 'wight' and could be transliterated as 'Elf-friend'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Surname Database|url=http://www.surnamedb.com/Surname/Wightman|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Rå]], spirits that protect natural features in later Scandinavian folklore * [[Wight]], for the usage of the term "wight" for living sentient beings in Old English, and later for ghost-like beings in modern fantasy works
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Sources== *''Folktales of Norway'', ed. Reidar Th. Christiansen, 1964. *''Scandinavian Folk Belief and Legend'', Reimund Kvideland & Henning K. Sehmsdorf, 1988. *''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xJkQAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false Norske Folke-Eventyr]'' (Norwegian Folktales), by [[Peter Christen Asbjørnsen]] & [[Jørgen Engebretsen Moe]], 1843, 1844, 1871, 1876.
==External links== *[http://www.ststlocations.com/Archives/Scandinavian/Folklore/ Scandinavian Folklore, compiled by Scott Trimble] - a scholarly outline of prominent themes in Scandinavian folklore.
{{Scandinavian folklore}}

[[da:Vætte]]
